Questions.question: Who was Norman Borlaug?
options:
important agricultural researcher that led the introduction of high yield crops in developing countries such as Mexico, India, and Pakistan 

 a radical left-wing extremist in the United States during WWI

 a prominent steel manufacturer in Pittsburgh who helped build military technology during WWI.

 a prominent scientist who attempted to bring agricultural practices of the United States to the countries of Africa

Questions.question: The Russo-Japanese war is a perfect example of:
options:
industrial might beats world power status 

 The continued importance of Europe and the United States in international affairs

 Russian naval dominance

 Japan's inability to deal with Russian military

Questions.question: All of the following are deep rooted issues in Europe that helped cause World War One except:
options:
Nationalism

 The Alliance System

 Imperialism

 The assassination of Franz Ferdinand

Questions.question: The Schlieffen Plan was the German plan to be used for a war against:
options:
Britain and France

 France and Russia 

 France and Italy

 Russia and Britain

Questions.question: Vladimir Lenin's simple phrase to gain support in Russia during the Russian Revolution was:
options:
“Land, Money, and Bread”

 "Peace, Money, and Support”

 “Peace, Land, and Bread” 

 “Peace, Land, and Relief”

Questions.question:
Use the following source describing Berlin factory work to answer the question.
	In every large works, and in the coordination of any large number of workmen, good order and harmony must be looked upon as the fundamentals of success, and therefore the following rules shall be strictly observed. Every man employed shall receive a copy of these rules, so that no one can plead ignorance. Its acceptance shall be deemed to mean consent to submit to its regulations.
	(1) The normal working day begins at all seasons at 6AM. precisely and ends, after the usual break of half an hour for breakfast, an hour for dinner and half an hour for tea, at 7 P.M., and it shall be strictly observed. Five minutes before the beginning of the stated hours of work until their actual commencement, a bell shall ring and indicate that every worker has to proceed to his place of work, in order to start as soon as the bell stops. The doorkeeper shall lock the door punctually at 6 AM., 8:30 AM., 1 P.M., and 4:30 P.M. Workers arriving two minutes late shall lose half an hour's wages; whoever is more than 2 minutes late may not start work until after the next break, or at least lose his wages until then. Any disputes about the correct time shall be settled by the clock mounted above the gatekeepers lodge. These rules are valid both for time and for piece-workers, and in cases of breaches of these rules, workmen shall be fined in proportion to their earnings. The deductions from the wage shall be entered in the wage-book of the gatekeeper whose duty they are; they shall be unconditionally accepted as it will not be possible to enter into any discussions about them.
	(2) When the bell is rung to denote the end of the working day, every workman, both on piece- and on day-wage, shall leave his workshop and the yard, but is not allowed to make preparations for his departure before the bell rings. Every breach of this rule shall lead to a fine of five silver groschen* to the sick fund. Only those who have obtained special permission by the overseer may stay on in the workshop in order to work. If a workman has worked beyond the closing bell, he must give his name to the gatekeeper on leaving, on pain of losing his payment for the overtime.
*Groschen was a German unit of currency

Source: Rules of a Factory in Berlin (1844), published in Perspectives from the Past (2009), pgs. 436-437.

The passage above reflects which of the following processes of the 18th and 19th centuries?
options:
The consolidation of power of the nation-state at every level of society

 The transition of project based labor to time based labor of the Industrial Revolution 

 The use of clocks to tell time and determine the working day

 The hierarchical nature of industrial based factory work

The hierarchical nature of factory work is best compared to which of the following?
options:
Feudalism in medieval Europe 

 Egyptian scribes in the Old Kingdom

 The division of the Mongol Empire into Khanates

 The Tang Dynasty's use of the civil service exam

Which piece of contextual evidence best describes why a rulebook such as the one above would be published?
options:
The Industrial Revolution led to overcrowding of factories, requiring rulebooks to maintain order

 Factory work introduced by the Industrial Revolution required a routinized working schedule, and specified rules allowed for the establishment of a routine 

 The Industrial Revolution required long hours and short breaks in order to turn a profit in the new economic markets of mass production

 Prussian cities were more devoted to maintaining rules and order within factories than other European industrial powers

Which of the following passages from the primary source most specifically shows the hierarchical nature of factory work?
options:
“Any disputes about the correct time shall be settled by the clock mounted above the gatekeepers lodge."

 "These rules are valid both for time- and for piece-workers, and in cases of breaches of these rules, workmen shall be fined in proportion to their earnings.”

This primary source would be most helpful for which of the following historical projects?
options:
A project concerning the number of factories that had rulebooks.

 A project concerning the relationship between the factory workers and their managers. 

 A project arguing for the importance of physical punishment within the workplace.

 A project concerning the use of verbal contracts between workers and their managers

Clergy

 nobility

 commoners

Economic Imperialism 

 Canton Trading System

 Realpolitik

 Hagiography

Questions.question:
Use the following document to answer the question.
"Thanks in no small measure to the presence of the clever and able diplomat Talleyrand, France, the cause of all the turmoil, got off lightly. Prussia would have severely punished and weakened France, but her three major colleagues were fearful of upsetting the balance of power. Already saddled with the restored Bourbons, France was merely reduced to almost the same it had had before the wars of the revolutionary era. The Congress of Vienna (1814-1815) had originally imposed no indemnity (fines) on France. But because of Napoleon's return from Elba in the midst of the congress and his 10Q-day fling that ended at Waterloo, the four great powers compelled France to cede the Saar basin to Prussia, to pay indemnity of 700 million francs, and to return the art treasures stolen by Napoleon from the various galleries of Europe."

Source: Sullivan, Richard. A Short History of Western Civilization (1994).

According to the above excerpt, which of the following is true?
options:
The major powers of Europe had punished France rather lightly in the beginning, but Napoleon's return made the punishments more severe 

 Prussia wanted France to give up all its territory to the other European powers

 The British sided with Napoleon during his brief 100-day reign in France

 Russia and Austria sided with Prussia in Prussia's quest to severely punish the French as early as 1814

Source: Sullivan, Richard. A Short History of Western Civilization (1994).

What major piece of historical context is crucial in order to understand the Congress of Vienna?
options:
The Renaissance

 The French Revolution 

 The Haitian Revolution

 The Prussian and Austrian rivalry

Which of the following would explain why Prussia would be especially harsh on the French during the Congress of Vienna?
options:
Otto von Bismarck wanted to unify Germany through Prussian dominance in Europe

 Napoleon’s wars took the largest toll on the Prussian countryside and Napoleon was excessively harsh towards the Prussians 

 Napoleon and Prussia had been in an intense rivalry since prior to the start of the French Revolution in 1801

 Prussia's quest for independence from the British would be fulfilled if they could remove French influence over German speaking territories
Stimulus MC

Questions.question: Who was Friedrich Engels?
options:
A German Enlightenment thinker

 The writing partner of Karl Marx 

 A leader of the French Revolution

 A British entrepreneur and inventor

Questions.question: All of the following would be considered examples of Eugenics except:
options:
Ellis Island immigration checkpoint

 Nazi calls for euthanization of mentally impaired children

 Judging a civilization based on their technological advances 

 Forced sterilization of the physically handicapped

options:
Sugar and Tobacco 

 Sugar and Cotton

 Cotton and Tobacco

 Tobacco and Indigo

Questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes Elmina Castle?
options:
Elmina Castle was a defensive fort and trading post used to facilitate trade between the Portuguese and the Africans. It is located on the western African coast, and was taken over by the Dutch in 1637. 

 Elmina Castle was a trading post on the eastern African coast that facilitated trade between the Spanish and Africans. It was also taken over by the Dutch in 1637.

 Elmina Castle was a defensive fort and trading post used to facilitate trade between the English and Indian merchants. It was taken over by the Dutch in 1637.

 Elmina Castle was a defensive fort and trading post used to facilitate trade between the Portuguese and the Africans. It is located in modern day Egypt and was taken over by the Dutch in 1637.

Questions.question: All of the following are negative consequences of the Columbian Exchange except
options:
The extensive use of feudalism 

 Creation of a class system in the Americas

 The Slave Trade

 The spread of disease

Questions.question: The Catalan Atlas was made in 1375, providing an extremely detailed map of Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and portions of India. Who made the Catalan Atlas?
options:
The Majorcan Cartographic School 

 Henry the Navigator

 Martin Behaim

 Juan de la Cosa

Questions.question: All of the following are important examples of interactions in the New World except
options:
While Europeans wanted to bring agricultural products like the potato back to the Old World, Europeans did not allow Old World products to be brought to the New World for production. 

 Europeans forced natives to work on plantations before many were killed by Old World diseases.

 Europeans set up powerful empires in North, South, and Central America,

 Europeans used the agricultural products of the New World for food production in the Old World.

Questions.question: Why did Haitian Vodou develop in the New World?
options:
Slaves were not allowed to practice their native religion, but were instead forced to convert to Christianity. Slaves continued to practice their own religion in secret, which led to the blending of the two religions. 

 Europeans allowed slaves to practice both Vodou and Christianity, and over time the two religions developed into one.

 Europeans encouraged multiple religious practices, and over time Haitian Vodou developed out of Judaism, Christianity and traditional Vodou.

 Slaves were not allowed to practice Vodou nor Christianity, and instead were forced to create a new religion by combining their religion and European religion.

Questions.question: Which of the following was the first European company to introduce stock options for investors?
options:
Dutch East India Company 

 English East India Company

 French East India Company

 Portuguese East India Company

options:
India 

 The Philippines

 Russia

 North American Colonies

Questions.question: These elite forces helped with the expansion of the Ottoman Empire
options:
Janissaries 

 Jesuits

 Turkish knights

 Rashidun

Questions.question: What statement best compares agricultural changes in the New World and the Old World due to the Columbian Exchange?
options:
In the New World, cash crops like sugar became the key agricultural product while potatoes and corn contributed to increased food production in the Old World. 

 In the New World, the importation of new grain crops provided a boost to New World food production while exotic crops like tomatoes had little impact on Old World agriculture.

 In the New World, little agricultural change occurred because the native population was devastated by disease; however, potatoes and corn contributed to population growth in Europe and China.

 In the New World, food production and cash crop production grew rapidly while the Old World experienced little agricultural changes.

Questions.question: Which European country is largely responsible for introducing the potato to early modern Europe?
options:
Spain 

 Portugal

 The Holy Roman Empire

 England

Questions.question: What was the first cash crop to be introduced to the New World?
options:
Sugar 

 Cotton

 Tobacco

 Okra

Questions.question: Which of the following is the most accurate when describing the Middle Passage?
options:
A leg in the triangular journey between the New And Old Worlds that involved the transportation of slaves from Africa to the New World 

 Trading route used to transport agricultural goods to and from the Old World

 A road that goes from the east side of modern day Mexico to the Pacific, and was used by the Spanish in early colonization

 Trading route used to transport cotton from India to Britain

Questions.question: Which two large economies suffered due to the establishment of a global silver trade?
options:
China and Spain 

 Spain and Portugal

 China and Portugal

 China and England

Questions.question:
Use the following source to answer the question.
"First, let us consider the inner man to see how a righteous, free, and pious Christian, that is, a spiritual, new, and inner man, becomes what he is. It is evident that no external thing has any influence in producing Christian righteousness or freedom, or in producing unrighteousness or servitude. A simple argument will furnish the proof of this statement. What can it profit the soul if the body is well, free, and active, and eats, drinks, and does as it pleases? For in these respects even the most godless slaves of vice may prosper. On the other hand, how will poor health or imprisonment or hunger or thirst or any other external misfortune harm the soul? Even the most godly men, and those who are free because of clear consciences, are afflicted with these things. None of these things touch either the freedom or the servitude of the soul." 

Source: Martin Luther, On Christian Liberty (1520). 

Based on the above passage, which of the following is true concerning Luther's interpretation of the human spirit?
options:
The inner man cannot be impacted, either negatively or positively, by external things 

 The inner man cannot be positively impacted by external things, but the inner man can be negatively impacted by them 

 "Godless slaves of vice" can enter heaven based on their eating habits 

 The most godly men have the highest likelihood of going to heaven

Questions.question:
Use the following source to answer the question.

Even the most godly men, and those who are free because of clear consciences, are afflicted with these things. None of these things touch either the freedom or the servitude of the soul." 

Source: Martin Luther, On Christian Liberty (1520). 

Why would the Catholic Church of the 1400s and 1500s stand against the writing in the passage above?
options:
The Catholic Church in this time promoted the vast accumulation of wealth

 The Catholic Church based much of its teachings on doing good works in order to get to heaven 

 Luther directly challenged the idea of free will 

 Catholics considered Luther's teachings on spirituality to be heretical

What general trend can we identify in early modern religious change?
options:
Early modern religions generally show a push in the direction of the importance of the spirit over earthly possessions or temptations. 

 Christianity, Buddhism, and Islam all show a serious push for interaction with political powers in their respective regions

 Christianity, Buddhism and Islam were all weak in the early modern period

 Christianity and Buddhism stayed united throughout the early modern period, while Islam split into two opposing groups.

 patriotism

upon initial contact, Europeans made consistent effort to colonize the interior regions

 resources such as gold and ivory were plundered

Questions.question: What is one major difference between the Enlightenment in Europe compared to the Enlightenment in the United States?
options:
The Enlightenment in Europe involved more successful revolutionary movements 

 Enlightenment in the United States was more religious than the Enlightenment in Europe 

 The Enlightenment in Europe involved people like John Locke, while the the Enlightenment in the United States used only American thinkers

 The Enlightenment in Europe ended in 1750, while the Enlightenment in the United States ended in 1800

options:
Otto von Bismarck 

 John Locke 

 Napoleon

Questions.question:
Use the following passage to answer the following question.
While America's military strength is important, let me add here that I've always maintained that the struggle now going on for the world will never be decided by bombs or rockets, by armies or military might. The real crisis we face today is a spiritual one; at root, it is a test of moral will and faith.
Whittaker Chambers, the man whose own religious conversion made him a witness to one of the terrible traumas of our time, the Hiss-Chambers case, wrote that the crisis of the Western World exists to the degree in which the West is indifferent to God, the degree to which it collaborates in communism's attempt to make man stand alone without God. And then he said, "for Marxism-Leninism is actually the second oldest faith, first proclaimed in the Garden of Eden with the words of temptation, 'Ye shall be as gods."
The Western world can answer this challenge, he [Chambers] wrote, "but only provided that its faith in God and the freedom He enjoins is as great as communism's faith in Man."
I believe we shall rise to the challenge. I believe that communism is another sad, bizarre chapter in human history whose last pages even now are being written. I believe this because the source of our strength in the quest for human freedom is not material, but spiritual. And because it knows no limitation, it must terrify and ultimately triumph over those who would enslave their fellow man. For in the words of Isaiah: "He giveth power to the faint; and to them that have no might; He increased strength But they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run, and not be weary."
Yes, change your world. One of our Founding Fathers, Thomas Paine, said, "We have it within our power to begin the world over again." We can do it, doing together what no one church could do by itself.
God bless you, and thank you very much.

Source: "Evil Empire Speech" Ronald Reagan, addressing the National Association of Evangelicals in Orlando, FL, 1983.

With delivering this speech, Ronald Reagan does which of the following?
options:
Announces his willingness to continue to make nuclear weapons 

 Uses concepts of democracy and capitalism in the face of communism 

 Utilizes religious tradition to turn the Cold War into an ideological struggle 

 Uses religious tradition to guilt citizens into supporting the Cold War

Questions.question:

While America's military strength is important, let me add here that I've always maintained that the struggle now going on for the world will never be decided by bombs or rockets, by armies or military might. The real crisis we face today is a spiritual one; at root, it is a test of moral will and faith.
Whittaker Chambers, the man whose own religious conversion made him a witness to one of the terrible traumas of our time, the Hiss-Chambers case, wrote that the crisis of the Western World exists to the degree in which the West is indifferent to God, the degree to which it collaborates in communism's attempt to make man stand alone without God. And then he said, "for Marxism-Leninism is actually the second oldest faith, first proclaimed in the Garden of Eden with the words of temptation, 'Ye shall be as gods."
The Western world can answer this challenge, he [Chambers] wrote, "but only provided that its faith in God and the freedom He enjoins is as great as communism's faith in Man."
I believe we shall rise to the challenge. I believe that communism is another sad, bizarre chapter in human history whose last pages even now are being written. I believe this because the source of our strength in the quest for human freedom is not material, but spiritual. And because it knows no limitation, it must terrify and ultimately triumph over those who would enslave their fellow man. For in the words of Isaiah: "He giveth power to the faint; and to them that have no might; He increased strength But they that wait upon the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings as eagles; they shall run, and not be weary."
Yes, change your world. One of our Founding Fathers, Thomas Paine, said, "We have it within our power to begin the world over again." We can do it, doing together what no one church could do by itself.
God bless you, and thank you very much.

Source: "Evil Empire Speech" Ronald Reagan, addressing the National Association of Evangelicals in Orlando, FL, 1983.

What piece of historical context most accurately describes the above passage?
options:
The Cold War had been dragging on for decades, and the Soviet Union had been weakening since the mid-1970s 

 The Soviet Union just collapsed, and Reagan was attempting to capitalize on that momentum 

 Nuclear production increased dramatically as soon as Reagan took office 

 Nixon's resignation turned public opinion against the Republican Party, and Reagan was trying to rebuild support among evangelicals

Which of the following most accurately describes Reagan's central argument found in the above passage?
options:
Americans must tap into their religious faith in order to defeat the communist threat 

 Americans, who represent God's children on Earth, must fight against communism, which is equated with the devil 

 Communism is the ultimate threat to democracy and the free market 

 Communism will grow unchecked unless the United States fights the threat

Questions.question:
Source: Early Trade Map of Africa, c. 1200-1450
Use the image to answer the question.
Which of the following arguments would be supported in the image shown?
options:
European colonization of Africa started in North Africa along the Trans-Saharan network 

 The Axum Empire dominated African trade along the entire eastern coastline

 African societies and states were well connected by trade routes in the Post-Classical era 

 The Mali Empire was at the center of the Trans-Saharan network

Questions.question:
Source: Early Trade Map of Africa, c. 1200-1450
Which of the following is likely true of the Trans-Saharan network during the period c. 1200-1450CE?
options:
The Roman Empire controlled all the Trans-Saharan Network

 The growth of African trade was facilitated by the rapid spread of Islam 

 The Roman Empire did not control North Africa, and were not critical in the Trans-Saharan network

 The growth of the Trans-Saharan Network was not encouraged by innovations in existing transportation technologies.

Questions.question:
Use the following passage to answer the question.
9. Free men who sire one or more children with slaves out of wedlock, together with the masters who permitted this, will each be condemned to a fine of two thousand pounds of sugar. And if they are the masters of the slave by whom they have had the said children, we wish that, in addition to the fine, they be deprived of the slave and the children, and that she and they be confiscated for the profit of the (royal] hospital, without ever being manumitted*. Nevertheless we do not intend for the present article to be enforced if the man was not married to another person during his concubinage** with his slave, and if he marries the said slave according to the church's formalities. She, then, by this means will be manumitted and the children rendered free and legitimate. 
12. Children who are borne of a marriage between slaves will be slaves and will belong to the master of the woman slave, and not to those of their husbands, if the husband and wife have different masters. 
13. We wish that if a slave husband has married a free woman, the children, both male and female, follow the condition of their mother and be free like her, in spite of the servitude of their father; and that if the father is free and the mother is enslaved, the children will likewise be slaves. 
*: Release from slavery, set free. 
**: The practice of keeping a concubine (a mistress) 

Source: "1685 Code Noir" (1685) in Slavery, Freedom, and the Law in the Atlantic World: A Brief History with Documents, Sue Peabody (2007), 31-32…

All of the following are ways this law code could be used in a court case in this colony except:
options:
A mother could use this document to have her children put under her care from their father

 A slave could use this to gain manumission if they married their owner 

 A slave master could use this document to have his male slave's children put under their father's care 

 The government could use this document to force a slave owner to pay a fine in sugar

Nevertheless we do not intend for the present article to be enforced if the man was not married to another person during his concubinage** with his slave, and if he marries the said slave according to the church's formalities. She, then, by this means will be manumitted and the children rendered free and legitimate.

The document above promotes which of the following about societal expectations in world history?
options:
The male or father is in charge of production and work 

 the female or mother is in charge of raising children 

 The status of the child follows the status of their father 

 Law codes tend to favor relationships that cross over social boundaries

Which of the following pieces of historical context explains the ideas of social hierarchy in the above passage?
options:
European expansion of plantation farming required cheap labor 

 European industrialization caused the need for cheap labor in their colonies 

 European wars caused a need for outside labor from slaves 

 European colonization in India caused the need for cash crops coming from the New World

Questions.question:
Use the following passage to answer the question. 
Like a good detective story, the history of capitalism begins with a puzzle. For millennia trade had flourished within traditional societies, strictly confined in its economic and moral reach. Yet in the sixteenth century, commerce had moved in bold new directions. More effective ways to raise food slowly started to release workers and money for other economic pursuits, tobacco, cotton, tea, and silks that came to Europe from the East and West Indies and beyond. These improvements raised the standard of living for Western Europeans, but it took something more dramatic to break through the restraints of habit and authority of the old economic order. That world reshaping force came when a group of natural philosophers gained an understanding of physical laws. With this knowledge, investors with a more practical bent found stunning ways to generate energy from natural forces. Production took a quantum leap forward. Capitalism - a system based on individual investments on the production of marketable goods - slowly replaced the traditional ways of meeting the material needs of a society. From early industrialization to the present global economy, a sequence of revolutions relentlessly changed the habits and habitats of human beings. The puzzle is why it took so long for these developments to materialize. 

Source: Joyce Appleby, The Relentless Revolution: A History of Capitalism (2010), 3-4

Based on the passage above, what is the main purpose of this book?
options:
To accurately explain the relationship between capitalism and the industrial revolution 

 To understand how the economy of the 16th century transitioned to capitalism 

 To describe the history of capitalism as it started in Europe 

 To understand why the development of capitalism happened when it did

Questions.question:
Use the following passage to answer the question. 
Like a good detective story, the history of capitalism begins with a puzzle. For millennia trade had flourished within traditional societies, strictly confined in its economic and moral reach. Yet in the sixteenth century, commerce had moved in bold new directions. More effective ways to raise food slowly started to release workers and money for other economic pursuits, tobacco, cotton, tea, and silks that came to Europe from the East and West Indies and beyond. These improvements raised the standard of living for Western Europeans, but it took something more dramatic to break through the restraints of habit and authority of the old economic order. That world reshaping force came when a group of natural philosophers gained an understanding of physical laws. With this knowledge, investors with a more practical bent found stunning ways to generate energy from natural forces. Production took a quantum leap forward. Capitalism - a system based on individual investments on the production of marketable goods - slowly replaced the traditional ways of meeting the material needs of a society. From early industrialization to the present global economy, a sequence of revolutions relentlessly changed the habits and habitats of human beings. The puzzle is why it took so long for these developments to materialize. 

Source: Joyce Appleby, The Relentless Revolution: A History of Capitalism (2010), 3-4

Based on the passage above, the growth of capitalism was caused by all of the following except:
options:
Industrialization in the 1700s and 1800s

 Developing ideas of investment and consumerism 

 The decline of production of sugar and tobacco plantations 

 The improvements of the standard of living in Europe.
